Award.AwardTitle: A Supramolecular Chemistry Approach to Precisely Controlled Multi-Porphyrin Arrays in Water
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division supports the project by Professor Jayawickramarajah, of the Department of Chemistry at Tulane University. Dr. Jayawickramarajah is developing an synthetic approach to make precisely controlled mutli-porphyrin arrays in water. The goal of this research is to design a system of 2-dimensional cyclic structures to form 3-dimensional cylinders that can improve light absorption and direction for electron transfer. The project uses a process called self-assembly, where the synthetic color molecules (porphyrins) spontaneously form the desired 3D architectures by mixing of carefully chosen components. Further, the project utilizes water (an abundant and non-toxic liquid) as the medium for the reaction. In addition to increasing our fundamental understanding of molecular assembly and light-collection, this project also includes an outreach component that focuses on enhancing the interest of K-12 students in chemistry and science.

The construction of defined 3D cylinders composed of multiple rungs of 2D cyclic chromophore arrays is attractive for photonic applications since such 3D architectures may provide enhanced light absorption, and directionality for excitation energy transfer (EET). The porphyrin rings can be packed densely onto functional solid substrates. The research team synthesizes the components and then studies the assembly of the cylinders in water. The strategy harnesses an array of supramolecular assembly modes, including cation-induced guanosine or isoguanosine oligonucleotide hybridization to form cylindrical quadruplexes and pentaplexes. Importantly, the researchers propose to position unique chromophores at specific sites along the cylinders to achieve directional EET. The light-harvesting porphyrins are precluded from undergoing detrimental self-stacking and thus exhibit superior photophysical properties. These properties are analyzed via steady-state and time-resolved fluorescence measurements that are conducted in collaboration with the Rubtsov and Schmehl research groups. The outreach plan includes a service-learning course pioneered by Professor Jayawickramarajah and focuses on undergraduates from Tulane conducting chemistry-centered service learning activities at inner-city New Orleans public schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Porphyrins and their congeners are vibrant pigments used as antennas in biological systems to capture solar energy that drive photosynthesis. In order to efficiently absorb and transport sunlight, Nature has evolved to arrange these pigments in a circular fashion. Inspired by the fascinating circular symmetry of natural antenna systems, the goal of this project was to engineer cylindrical structures composed of multiple rungs of circularly arranged pigments. The rationale for developing such pigment containing cylinders is because cylinders are ideal 3 dimensional geometric shapes for light-funneling due to their directionality as well as their vertical packing capability. To make such cylindrical architectures with interesting photonic properties, we proposed an approach that uses the programmed interactions of DNA sequences appended to pigment molecules. Importantly, in our approach we designed pigments that are protected by molecular cages to ensure that the pigments had enhanced light absorbing and emitting properties.

 

Through this grant, we have now developed synthetic strategies to obtain porphyrin pigments that are attached to (a) cyclic sugar containing cages (cyclodextrins), and (b) to short self-assembling DNA strands. Upon self-assembly, these DNA sequences form nanocylinders wherein the pigments are arranged with nanoscale precision and are also very bright (up to 180-times brighter than similar systems lacking the sugar cages). We have also prepared nanocylinders with rungs of pigment molecules on one end that can absorb light energy and transfer the excitation to other pigments further down the cylinder. In addition, we have developed various systems to probe how synthetic hosts (cages) can interact with pigments and how DNA-assembly can be used to probe host-guest interactions. These studies have enhanced our fundamental understanding of how to engineer directional nanostructures that may lead to novel photonic systems with possible applications in solar energy harvesting and in imaging and detection technologies.

 

The results from this grant have been published in well-reputed peer-reviewed journals. This grant has also supported 2 PhD theses and 1 Masters thesis. In addition to furthering scientific knowledge in chemistry, photonics, and nanotechnology, this project has also integrated research with service-learning and community outreach. Specifically, the PI has taught a course, titled "Chemistry Outreach in New Orleans" that involves Tulane undergraduate students (along with a couple of graduate students) performing chemistry demonstrations at local, inner-city, New Orleans schools. The goals (to engender an increased interest in STEM fields for the predominantly under-represented minority K-12 school population, as well as the Tulane undergrads), key findings, and instructive experience, from this course have also been published.
